results.title: Return from the road
results.brief_description: Short film starring US comedian Harvey Korman as a travelling salesman just returned from a long sales trip, tired, hungry and frustrated. With an unco-operative wife who won’t cook and then makes him sleep on the couch, he dreams of what might have been. News of the imminent arrival of his mother-in-law turns his thoughts to the road again.

results.title: Retirement villages: a consumer guide
results.creator_credit: Village Communique, Andrea Philipp and Garry McKechnie
results.brief_description: Buying into a retirement village is a big step and one that leads to further, more complicated issues. This series of 3 videos and booklet attempts to work through these issues and help make the final decision about buying into a retirement village, an informed one. The 3 tapes cover lifestyle, financial and legal issues. The book provides a step by step guide to the process as a whole.

results.title: Retirement income perils
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Sally Wiadrowski
results.brief_description: In this “4 Corners” special, reporter Chris Masters investigates an area which is causing plenty of grey hairs - Retirement Investment Planning - RIP. This is an overview of the efficacy of superannuation savings and how it will or will not allow people to live comfortably after retirement.

results.title: Rethinking rape (Captioned)
results.brief_description: This is an in depth look at rape, particularly rape perpetrated by people known to the victim. In order to understand the high frequency of rape and its social causes, we must examine our cultural attitudes towards women, male/female relationships and rape itself. Six people of varying backgrounds, including a Rape Crisis Centre director, and a social psychologist, share their perspective’s on this topic.

results.title: Reternity: design of the 20th century
results.creator_credit: Futurniture, Torbjorn Lenskog, Johanna Ekstrom and Annika Eriksson
results.brief_description: In the winter of 1996-97, four Swedish and two British artists took part in an exhibition centred on Torbjorn Lenskog’s extensive collection of 20th century design objects at the Swedish National Art Museum. Their works engaged with the social life of these objects as design icons, addressing everything from the mentality of collecting, through the ideologies that informed modernism to the cultural malleability of industrial products. For this CD-ROM box set these artist were invited once again to make work in relation to the collection, this time specifically for the digital medium. The goal, as for the exhibition, was to stage a kind of confrontation between different ways of looking at history and its products. In addition to their works, which encompass a wide range of media, the CDs contain a large number of advertising images and photographs of the products in use, as well as excerpts from over 60 post-war documentaries that shed light on the industrial and social context that informed the design and reception of the objects. Quicktime objects and panoramas provide a close up of the items in collection.

results.title: Retail stock management
results.creator_credit: World Wide Pictures, Peter Bradford and James Allen
results.brief_description: A film designed for retailers showing quite simply how stock control helps a shopkeeper to increase his stock turnover and therefore profits.

results.title: Resurrection
results.brief_description: Based on Leo Tolstoy’s novel this is a story of seduction and abandonment, guilt and redemption. Cast includes Arthur V. Johnson, Florence Lawrence, Marion Leonard, Owen Moore, Mack Sennett. Silent film with no intertitles.

results.title: Restoring the past
results.creator_credit: Bosisto Productions, South Australian Film Corporation, Bruce Moir and Mario Andreacchio
results.brief_description: Examines correct and incorrect procedures in restoring old buildings. The audience is taken on an informative journey around Adelaide historic buildings, where restoration is looked at through the many errors that have been made and the current restoration of a number of buildings under the guidance of the Australian Mineral Development Laboratories. Great footage of early South Australian buildings.
